mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\cos{\theta}\!=\!\cos{\tilde{\theta}}\;[1-\Delta_{2}(\sin^{2}{\!\tilde{\theta}%
}-\Delta^{2}_{2})/(4\cos^{2}{\!\tilde{\theta}})]." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mpadded width="-1.7pt"><mi>θ</mi></mpadded></mrow><mo rspace="0.8pt">=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><mover accent="true"><mi>θ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover></mpadded></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="-1.7pt"><msup><mi>sin</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mpadded><mo>⁡</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>θ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover></mrow><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mn>2</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>/</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mpadded width="-1.7pt"><msup><mi>cos</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mpadded><mo>⁡</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>θ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where we have used that $H = 2 \cos{\tilde \theta} [J({\bf 0}) - J({\bf Q}_{\nu})]$ to zeroth order in $\Delta_2$.
It is clear from this expression that the energy is a decreasing function of $\Delta_2$ for small enough $\Delta_2$.
In particular, if we assume that $A \ll J(2 {\bf Q}_3) - J ({\bf 0}) $, we can minimize \eqref{energy2} as a function of $x$ to obtain.
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="E(\Delta_{2})-E(\Delta_{2}=0)=\left[\frac{J(2{\bf Q}_{3})-J({\bf 0})}{32}+%
\frac{9A}{8}\right]x^{4}\cos^{2}{\!\tilde{\theta}}-\frac{Ax^{2}}{2}\cos^{2}{\!%
\tilde{\theta}}+{\cal O}(\Delta^{5}_{2})" display="block"><mrow><mi>E</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>E</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mi>J</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>𝐐</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>J</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn/><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mn>32</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>9</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow><mn>8</mn></mfrac><mo>]</mo></mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mpadded width="-1.7pt"><msup><mi>cos</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mpadded><mover accent="true"><mi>θ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mpadded width="-1.7pt"><msup><mi>cos</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mpadded><mover accent="true"><mi>θ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo>+</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒪</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext:
where we have used that $H = 2 \cos{\tilde \theta} [J({\bf 0}) - J({\bf Q}_{\nu})]$ to zeroth order in $\Delta_2$.
It is clear from this expression that the energy is a decreasing function of $\Delta_2$ for small enough $\Delta_2$.
In particular, if we assume that $A \ll J(2 {\bf Q}_3) - J ({\bf 0}) $, we can minimize \eqref{energy2} as a function of $x$ to obtain.
